You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 728, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 905, 840]]<|/det|>

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the rate of cooling, in air, of heated blocks made of different metals. The temperature of each block is increased by placing it in hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the rate of cooling depends on the metal from which each block is made.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 526, 182]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 537, 213]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 918, 259]]<|/det|>
cylindrical blocks of different metals, each with a hole for a thermometer, as shown in Fig. 4.1 a thermometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 740, 291]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 324, 321]]<|/det|>

<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 136, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 507, 431]]<|/det|>
